citation.article-title: Methanococcus jannaschii sp. nov., an extremely thermophilic methanogen from a submarine hydrothermal vent.

p.s: Description of Methanococcus jannaschii sp. nov.
Methanococcus jannaschii (jan. nasch. i. i. M.L. gen. n. jannaschii of Jannasch. The organism is named for the marine microbiologist Holger Jannasch.
Morphology.
Irregular cocci measuring 1.5 μm in diameter, occuring singly or in pairs.
Cells are osmotically fragile and easily lysed in low osmolal solutions.
Single electron dense cell wall; surface is composed of hexagonally ordered substructures; cells are motile; two bundles of flagella insert near one pole.
Colony characteristics.
Convex, circular, yellowish in color with a smooth shiny surface.
DNA base composition. 31 tool % G + C.
Temperature relationship.
Optimum near 85°C; range 50-85°C.
pH relationship.
Optimum near 6.0; growth occurs at pH 5.2 to 7.0.
Physiology.
Obligately anaerobic.
H2+CO2 serve as substrate for growth and CH4 formation.
Nutrition.
Grows autotrophically in defined medium with H2 + CO2.
NaCl required for growth (optimal at 0.5 M Na+).
Selenium stimulates growth.
Sulfide is required.
Source.
Sedimentary material at base of a "white smoker" submarine hydrothermal vent, East Pacific Rise, at a depth of 2,600 m.
Type strain.
JAL-1 has been deposited in the German culture collection (DSM) Göttingen, FRG, number 2661.
